BIOTECHNOLOGICAL POTENTIAL OF FILAMENTOUS FUNGI IN THE USE OF 2,4 -D HERBICIDE AS A CARBON SOURCE

Currently, soil contamination exacerbated by herbicides has represented a worrying scenario in several industrial and agricultural sectors. The 2,4 - Dichlophenoxyacetida acid (2,4 -D) was used in this study because it is the second most used and marketed herbicide in Brazil. Since it is highly lipophilic, it generates high accumulation in the soil and agricultural products. Therefore, new ways to recover contaminated soils , such as biodegradation by filamentous fungi, are essential. In this work, a screening of filamentous fungi, previously isolated from soil contaminated with 2,4-D, was carried out to select a microorganism that presented the most significant potential for degradation through analysis of radial growth. These tests occurred with two concentrations of 2,4 -D (250 and 500ppm) as the only carbon source and another for the same concentrations and with the malt -agar medium. Subsequently, by optical microscopy for analysis of microculture on slides, the most promising microorganism was identified as belonging to the genus Trichoderma. The fermentation step using the microorganism was developed with a medium containing 2,4 -D (250ppm) with and without 15.0 g/L of malt extract, with agitation at 160 and 200rpm, at a constant temperature of 28¬∞C for 7 days. Aliquots were withdrawn daily, and subsequently, the supernatant was separated for enzyme activity analyses. Laccase activity of 342¬±85U/l was detected on the seventh day of fermentation, with the medium containing malt extract + 2,4 -D (250ppm) under agitation at 160rpm. Furthermore, a maximum production of Manganese peroxidase (MnP) of 7188¬±23U/L was observed in a medium containing only 2,4 -D (250ppm) with the system under agitation at 160rpm. The percentage of maximum degradation obtained was 30.2¬±5.6% for the medium containing only 2,4 -D under agitation at 160 rpm. The results provided in this study corroborate with a future implementation of a bioremediation process in the soil using the selected fungus.
